[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker manipulate the chain_id parameter to inject path traversal sequences (e.g., '../', './') into the returned folder prefix, potentially allowing access to or overwriting of files outside the intended snapshot directory? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Integer Overflow] If chain_id approaches u64::MAX, could the format!() macro's string allocation fail or cause memory exhaustion when constructing the snapshot folder prefix, leading to denial of service? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Collision Attack] Can two different chain_id values produce the same snapshot_folder_prefix string through integer wraparound or formatting quirks, allowing snapshot data from one chain to overwrite or corrupt another chain's data? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Format String Injection] Does the format!() macro properly sanitize the chain_id u64 value, or could special formatting of large integers introduce unexpected characters into the folder name that might be interpreted as filesystem commands? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Resource Exhaustion] If this function is called repeatedly with varying chain_id values in a tight loop, could the String allocations cause memory pressure or heap fragmentation, potentially destabilizing the indexer service? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Race Condition] If multiple threads call snapshot_folder_prefix() with the same chain_id simultaneously and then create directories, could this lead to TOCTOU (Time-of-Check-Time-of-Use) vulnerabilities where an attacker swaps the directory between prefix generation and actual usage? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Naming Ambiguity] Does the prefix pattern 'snapshot_chain_{}_epoch_' create any ambiguity where a malicious actor could craft a folder name that matches this prefix but doesn't follow the expected structure, potentially confusing the backup/restore logic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_prefix()] [Special Characters] Can chain_id values cause the generation of folder names with special characters (e.g., null bytes, control characters) that might be interpreted differently by different filesystems, leading to inconsistent behavior across platforms? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker supply crafted chain_id or epoch values that inject directory traversal sequences into the returned folder name, potentially allowing snapshot files to be written to or read from arbitrary filesystem locations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Collision Attack] Can two different (chain_id, epoch) pairs produce identical snapshot_folder_name strings, causing one chain's snapshot to overwrite another's and leading to data loss or restoration of incorrect blockchain state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Integer Overflow] If both chain_id and epoch are near u64::MAX, could the combined string allocation in format!() fail or cause memory exhaustion, leading to service crashes during critical snapshot operations? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Epoch Manipulation] If epoch values can be manipulated by an attacker (e.g., through consensus bugs), could they craft epoch numbers that create snapshot folder names overlapping with legitimate snapshots, causing data corruption during backup/restore? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Symlink Attack] After snapshot_folder_name() returns a path, could an attacker create a symbolic link at that location before the snapshot is written, redirecting snapshot data to an attacker-controlled location or sensitive system files? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Format String] Does the format!() macro properly handle edge cases where chain_id or epoch are 0, u64::MAX, or other boundary values that might produce unexpected string representations? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/lib.rs] [Function: snapshot_folder_name()] [Race Condition] If multiple indexer instances call snapshot_folder_name() concurrently with the same chain_id and epoch, could this lead to race conditions where both try to create/write to the same snapshot directory simultaneously, causing data corruption?
